answers.answer: Have you gone back to the cardiologist?  You may have developed atrial fibrillation or atrial flutter which is not uncommon.  Your "fluttering" can be caught by wearing a holter monitor several weeks.  I would suggest that you make that appointment to ease your mind and find out what is going on.ksig

question: Two years ago I had a heart attack (female aged 58 at the time) and subsequent 6 way bi-pass surgery which went very well without any complications.  About a month ago, out of the blue my hear started 'fluttering' several times a day, mostly when I was at rest (or maybe I just noticed it then).  After about a week of this every day occurrence was about ready to call the doctor when just as suddenly it stopped as suddenly as it started.  Just out of the blue it would 'gallop' taking my breath away, then it would beat normally for a few hours.  Is this something I should be very worried about?  I know that sometimes it's hard to diagnose a woman having a heart attack, they delayed my treatment because even I thought I just had the flu.  I was throwing up and the left side of my chest & back hurt.  After the surgery my surgeon told me I had scarring from an old heart attack years ago....I remember about ten years ago, an episode where I couldn't stop throwing up for two days and I had abdominal pain.  All of this really scared me because I had no clue and I didn't know I had diabetes 2 either.  Now the flutter does worry me...should I be?
title: odd flutters
